turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: But those are our dreams, son. We have to make them come true.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Consider me your fairy godfather, except without the fairy part. No more mealy apples and bruised bananas, ever, for the rest of your lives.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Sorry I--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's okay. You need me?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Your mom said you've been ignoring your chores.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I paid off the mortgage! I ordered that Winnebago you always wanted! Now you're ashamed of me?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: You ordered a Winnebago?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: THAT is your dream, not mine. My dream is so far beyond anything YOU PEOPLE could even imagine.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Watch your tone, mister.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Why don't you just admit what this is really all about? I'm not your real kid and you can't control me anymore.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Shut your pie hole, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I will not have my boys arguing.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I-I don't have the keys.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: They're in the ignition, silly.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: You do know how to drive?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't have much experience with a...uh...stick.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Want a lesson?

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Now release the brake. And slide the stick into first gear.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: The first time can be awkward. You just have to get on and try again.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't even know if I should be doing this. It's a very expensive car.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: It's your car. These are all your cars.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Some of them have to be automatics.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Your father liked shifting. He said it brought him closer to the engine. "Like a woman, purring with ecstasy."

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm Ted, by the way. I think I forgot to say that.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: I know.  I'm Ginger. Miss April.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The one with the horses.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I almost didn't recognize you without...you know...that stallion between...your...uh...legs.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Hey, Ted. Wanna go shopping?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Shopping, really? I should tell my friend.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Don't worry.  He found the chocolate room.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hi ho, Silver.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Who exactly ARE you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What do you mean? I'm Ted Nelson.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: And who IS Ted Nelson?

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Or do you have a taste for the good life, Ted? It's in your blood.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I always knew there was more. I felt it.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Then remember, you are the heir to a billion dollar empire. You have a staff of literally thousands. Multiply everything you ever imagined by a million and you still can't even wrap your head around everything that is yours. ALL YOURS.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Teddy? I was thinking.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hmmm?

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: After graduation...maybe we could go away together?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Whatever you want.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Teddy, I thought we were having a moment here.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Of course we were.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Ted! Do something!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: This is humiliating. We're being ejected from a prom!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hang in there, I'll think of something.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess...I don't know...I guess we should leave if we're not wanted.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Oh, sweetheart! We wish we could be right there to hug the living daylights out of you!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: But if you're watching this, then it means we bit the dust.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: But don't worry...we'll be in heaven. The REAL heaven, I mean. Not that heaven is an actual place, but more like a state of being. Or not being. Who knows. Maybe we know now.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: If you're anything like yours truly, then you probably figure we didn't want you when you were born, so who cares if we're dead? Am I right?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: But we did want you. It's just that you don't always get to keep what you want. We knew you needed a real mom and dad.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We had no idea the nudie magazine we started in the garage would turn into all this.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Can you believe that was me?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Before we knew it, we created the most popular men's magazine in the entire nation. The rest is history.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: So here we are. Dead. But we never want you to want for anything. That is, we want you to have everything.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Everything.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're on the next plane home.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I'm Helen McDole.  Your father's executive secretary.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No problem, consider it done.  I had this idea of shooting on location. Outdoors, you know? Maybe at some famous Xenia landmarks. You think that would be a problem?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: We'll send you the release forms, Ted. Our staffers will help in any way they can.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: It's a little more serious than that, Bill. The stockholders have requested a meeting. They want our guarantee that this will never happen again.  Some of them are even calling for Ted's resignation.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, the girls of Xenia are gorgeous, you'll see. Next month we'll be back to normal.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Your parents never wanted to interfere with your life, Ted. They knew your Mom and Dad loved you very much. They knew they did the right thing. But that doesn't mean they didn't watch you and miss you, from afar.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You mean they knew who I was?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: They kept this scrapbook of your life. It meant the world to them.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I wondered about them, for so many years. I wondered if I looked like them, acted like them. I wondered why they gave me up.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Giving you up was the most unselfish thing they ever did. When they founded "Heaven," they wished they could take you back but it was too late. All they could do was build the empire, knowing that someday it would all be yours.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My legacy.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Your parents would be crushed to think you weren't happy with it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: They're not my parents, Helen. My parents are back in Xenia and I hurt them very much.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And the girl I love, she hates "Heaven." If I keep it, she'll never respect me.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: But how can you respect yourself if you don't?

turns.speaker: JAY
turns.text: How are the hometown folks treating you, back in Xenia?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, Jay. They've been exceptionally supportive.

turns.speaker: JAY
turns.text: Are they hitting you up for donations? Asking you to sponsor the local quilting bee?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm no stranger to the notion of philanthropy. Andrew Carnegie has long been one of my idols.

turns.speaker: JAY
turns.text: What about the future? You planning to rock the boat at all? Stir things up in "Heaven?"

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Matter of fact, Jay, my uncle and I are planning to rethink the magazine. To expand the traditional western notions of "beauty."

turns.speaker: JAY
turns.text: I see, so you'd be open to little ladies from Pasadena, who want to show you their knickers?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Matter of fact, Jay, I'm planning a pictorial focusing on the women of my hometown, "The Girls of Xenia." Just to show my appreciation.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Mom, Dad. Meatloaf has come to represent all that Ted hates about his mediocre life and the world we live in. He's what you'd call clinically bummed.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Why can't we have pot roast or stroganoff or even a little London broil? I mean, for god's sake, we own a grocery store!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: James, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: You can call me Jimmy again. Sheryl Petersen said James sounds too pretentious.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sheryl Petersen is, what, nine years old, what does she know?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: She knew exactly where you were staying, which you neglected to tell me, your own brother.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's really late...do your parents know where you are?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Impressive. This is bigger than our whole house.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Most places are, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: They say money can't buy happiness but this is a reasonably good facsimile.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So, what brings you here at his hour?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: My new bike.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Very funny.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I came to ask permission to take custody of your room.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My room?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Better view, more spacious, new carpet. It's a no-brainer.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's not up to me.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Mom and Dad said it's yours. They seem to think you're coming home.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You can have it, then. I'm not going back there.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: If you could just sign right there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You want it in writing?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Just a formality.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's it? I mean, you don't want to order room service or anything? We could play games and watch movies and stuff.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Are you kidding? Mom and Dad discover I'm gone and I'll be doing hard time.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are they okay?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Aside from the fact that Mom's eyes are nearly swollen shut from crying and Dad spends all his time under the car trying to fix stuff that isn't broken, things couldn't be better.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I miss them, too.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: You can't come back. That is, you can, but your things will be in the room you currently think of as mine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're a peach.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Funny you should say that. My Grandfather was a peach farmer.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He was my Grandfather, too.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I meant biologically.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's a crappy thing to say.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Look Ted. I'm cool with everything. You've long been dissatisfied with our mediocre little town. You've always had an itch for the good life. I'm happy for you. This couldn't happen to a nicer guy.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: But just for the record, my Mom is a kick-ass schoolteacher and my Dad is the best damn auto mechanic this side of the Himalayas. You seem to have forgotten they opened Nelson's FAMILY Market so they could build something permanent, a legacy, for us. Their kids.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I didn't forget.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: You ever look down on them again and call them "grocers" like it's a dirty word, and you'll be sucking your filet mignon through a straw for six to eight weeks. Got it?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: From my wise, albeit youthful, vantage point, the world is your oyster. You scored big.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: So, William Randolph. Your last big scoop contrasted the popularity of Rice Crispie Treats and chocolate Snickerdoodles at the annual bake sale.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's just one example. My reporting has made a difference.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Let me guess: retail sales of little chocolate sprinkles have gone through the roof!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The school dumpsters used to overflow to the point where the stench was unbearable. My award winning exposé changed all that. The city added an extra weekday trash pick-up.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Is it true? Is ignorance bliss?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, I loved "Exposed!" and I hate it that you got busted. I know the school paper sucks in comparison, but it's really not THAT BAD.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Don't even tell me you're hot for Miss Titty Pom Poms over there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Christy's a very talented journalist. I see a Pulitzer in her future.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I didn't know they gave them for Best Lip Gloss Retention During a Blow Job.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Me-ow.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Go ahead. Ask her to the prom. Get it over with.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I have absolutely no intention--

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: --Do it. I triple-dog-dare you.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I tried to warn you, William Randolph. She's got stiletto heels hidden in those Keds.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But you triple-dog-dared me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It was for your own good, in a twisted sort of publicly humiliating way.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: A few billion bucks and suddenly he's Cro-Magnon Man of the Year.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's so nice to have FRIENDS like you, Christy.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What is it, William Randolph? Your balls need scratching?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Your article sucked.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: In what sense?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: In the sense that there is no "hidden agenda" behind a bake sale that raised five hundred dollars for seeing eye dogs.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Ah ha! It was so well hidden, you didn't even know it was there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Come on, Julie. Don't screw up. You have some real talent.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Just because someone died and made you king of the publishing world doesn't mean you're even one ounce smarter than you were a week ago.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm trying to help.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'm still better than you. Nothing changed except the decimal point in your savings account.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's not ENTIRELY true.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What do you want from me? I'm trying to be fair. But I can't keep you on staff if you turn every PTA meeting into an Agent Orange cover up.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Then I'll write about YOU.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: "Local boy inherits more money than god." Call me crazy, but I smell human interest.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really? You wanna write about me?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I have to admit, I always felt... different.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Different how? Different like a dwarf at a basketball game? Or different like a lesbian in pumps?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't get the distinction.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Could everybody else tell you were different, or were you the only one who knew?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I felt limited. I felt confined. I felt like I was suffocating.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I see. So more like a tight rope walker who secretly wants to be a trapeze artist.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Interesting.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: She said peanuts, you cretin.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You never know around here.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't write that part.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Is this an gritty exposé or a candy ass press release?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Write what you want. Just try not to make it so obvious that you're crazy about me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Life must be peachy on Planet Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Funny you should say "peachy."

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I did my homework. Your grandfather was a peach farmer.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My adoptive grandfather. Who knows what my biological grandfather did.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Undoubtedly an aristocratic bartender of some sort.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Considering this is your first time on a private jet, on which you are interviewing the world's most eligible bachelor,  you are extremely cavalier.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I bet there are lots and lots of mirrors on Planet Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See? You're impertinent, rude, sarcastic.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: And this is not my first time on a private jet, so quit acting like I'm Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A little respect would be nice, that's all.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well? What do you think of her?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You're so twitterpated you don't even see the miner's hat and the pickax.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're implying she's, what, a gold digger?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Charlie's right. Jealousy is so unattractive.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Second only to unbridled, narcissistic conceit.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Why can't you be nice to me?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You've got enough people kissing your ass.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wow...you clean up nice.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Put your eyeballs back in your head, William Randolph. I'm on assignment. A girl has to fit in.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: To the best hiding place in the world.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I can't believe your dad built this for you.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: He didn't. He had it built.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Not "whatever."  It's two different things.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He cared enough to want you to have it.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: He phoned it in.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I doubt it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now it makes sense, the whole neo Bohemian, down with hypocrisy, fight the power crap. You're a poor little rich girl.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: The ozone must be fully depleted on Planet Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You think my dad would have been like that if I knew him? You think he would have bought me a stadium, instead of teaching me how to play ball?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Your dad taught you everything.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I mean my father.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: A father is nothing but sperm, Ted. It takes a real man to be a dad.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's all so complicated.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's incredibly simple.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I feel like I'm being drawn and quartered. Like every part of me is being pushed and pulled and tugged in a different direction.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Eventually you'll let go.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And then what?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Then you'll see who's really holding on to you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're amazing.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Even when you infuriate me, I still want to kiss you.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: But you never do.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: If we were a team, we could do anything. I mean, anything.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Cut to the chase, William Randolph. Your audience is way ahead of you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: In a word: MERK. EXPOSED.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That's two words. And I'm out of the "exposed" business, remember? I need to graduate. Besides, Merk's a boy scout.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: There's gotta be something. We have to dig deeper.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You forget, I dislike YOU at least as much as him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He shut down your paper!  You're stuck writing articles about swap meets and raffles and PTA brunches!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: A good journalist can take lemons and make lemonade. I'm honing my craft.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Then you won't mind covering that watermelon seed spitting contest next week...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's probably my office.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Well? Where the hell are you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He's on the move?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I got an anonymous tip and an address in Cincinnati.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Let's do it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know. This place seems pretty tame.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You expected whips, chains, Merk being cattle-prodded by some dominatrix in a leather hood?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: At least it's not another 4-H meeting or a Big Brother barbecue.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Amen to that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look at us. It's one o'clock in the morning, on a school night. We're in a smoky nightclub, hoping to catch our principal with some big city tart.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'm trembling with excitement.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That has more to do with your proximity to me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: My desire betrays me, like goosebumps on my flesh.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I have a bit of a goosebump fetish. Not many people know that.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I figured you for more of a hairy armpit guy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Shoes, if you want to know the truth. Shoes are my thing.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Wearing them?  Or humping them?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My fantasy is a totally naked woman, wearing nothing but a Timex and suede clogs.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That's refreshingly deviant.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What about you?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'm very aural.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Tell me more.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Sounds, voices, music, humming. All of it can turn me on, or off, like a switch.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I had a Portuguese boyfriend who could read the phone book and melt me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A Portuguese boyfriend. Sounds very "Cosmo."

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You live and learn. I realized the most important thing to me, above all, is trust.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Turned out to be a scoundrel, eh? I saw that one coming.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You lose trust in someone and it's over, done, gone, forever.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Do you trust me, Julie?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Not a chance.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Trust is something you earn, over time. You don't just inherit it overnight like a gazillion dollar empire.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I want you to trust me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Maybe someday.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Julie, I'll tell you something that is the god's honest truth. I've seen a lot of really beautiful girls. I mean a lot. But none of them make me feel like you do.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That's hard to believe.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But absolutely true.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I have to be honest with you, Ted. I really despise "The Girls of Xenia."

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I know, their small town mentality can be maddening.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I mean your pictorial. It bothers me, profoundly.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Aw Julie, it's my job. It's like being a doctor.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You're telling me you don't get aroused by a roomful of naked breasts.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You've seen one naked breast, you've seem them all.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Which explains the continued success of "Heaven" for how many decades?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're quick. I like that.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You think you're working with chimps here?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The thing is, I made a commitment. I said I'd do it and I have to keep my word.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Keeping your word is something I can actually respect, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Julie, wow. I was afraid you left. I was afraid I'd never see you again.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'm not going anywhere, Ted. You're the one with the champagne wishes and caviar dreams.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I decided to let Helen run the magazine. I need to go to college, learn a few things, you know.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And I thought maybe I'd take up boating. I've always wanted to be a "coxswain."

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Very ambitious. I like that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The thing is, I'll need a first mate.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I know where you can find any number of naked girls who'd love to hop on board.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Planet Ted. Five years from now. What's happening?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I graduated from college. Did great, summa cum laude and all. And I'm about to launch a brand new magazine called "EXPOSED!"  An homage to Miss Julie Conroy of Xenia, Ohio.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I know where you can find an excellent editor-in-chief.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yellow pages?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Let your fingers do the walking.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: They're playing our song.  Dare I ask for this dance?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You better.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What is this? Does everybody know everything I'm about to say or do every freakin' minute of the day?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: No cursing in this house, young man. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't have a shred of privacy in this whole stupid town!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: That's part of growing up, honey.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What? Having spring break ruined by will readings?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What about Charlie?  You boys could make it a little adventure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Charlie, at a will reading? What did I do to deserve this?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm all right, Mom. I'm not in Siberia, you know.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Did you have a nice flight?  Are they taking good care of you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, I'm doing fine.  I have so much to tell you.  I don't even know where to begin.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Save it, honey.  We want to hear every detail when you get back, but we don't want you to run up Mr. Zukerman's phone bill.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's okay, Mom.  Trust me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well? Surprised?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What is all this? When are you coming home?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Just a few tokens of my affection. I'll be back soon, don't worry.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Everything is lovely, Ted, but much too expensive.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mom. Believe me. I could buy all that AND the factories they came from.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh, good lord. Are those Neptunes?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Only the best for my mother.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You promise you'll finish school?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'll make you very proud.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You don't have to work another day in your lives.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: But how would we pay our bills?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't you get it? In one day I earn more interest than the store's entire annual revenue.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh. Goodness.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're free.  You can do anything you ever wanted to do!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Like take that trip to Buckingham Palace. Go deep sea fishing in the Gulf of Mexico. Now's your chance.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: But who would run the store?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Forget the store. Think big.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Everything I am is because of you. Can you ever forgive me?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh, Teddy. We missed you so much.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I need your help.  I'm really in deep shit.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Don't say "shit," honey. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: I like you, Ted. You know that. I liked you before you were filthy rich.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thanks, Principal Merkin.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: I'll be blunt. I know you can take it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yes, sir. I'll brace myself.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Ted, you are the best editor this school paper ever had. You don't need to be pandering flesh. It's nonsense. It's beneath you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You think I ought to just tell them thanks but no thanks? I don't want your silly billion dollar empire?

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: That's a good start, yes. A very good start.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you kidding? This magazine is my dream. It's every red-blooded, heterosexual male's dream.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: I never figured you for a pimp.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Have you ever even looked at "Heaven?"

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: What kind of sick question is that? I'll be watching you, young man. Your money and power mean nothing here. Nothing.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess you won't be wanting that Rolex I sent you, then?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: With all due respect to Merk, he doesn't have to read my magazine. But he has no right to stop others.  Ever hear of the First Amendment?

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: We cannot afford free speech if it excises the moral fiber of this community!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: If that were true, this would be one seriously constipated town. Most guys in Xenia have been looking at naked girls in "Heaven" since they were old enough to figure out their dads hide it under the mattress.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Honestly, Merk. It's like you were never seventeen and the head of a media empire.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Rules are rules.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Come on, it's our only senior prom.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Deaf ears, Mr. Nelson. I answer to a higher power.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: You're crossing the line, Mr. Nelson.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A statue in front of city hall, dedicated to Principal Dick Merkin?

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: I'm warning you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A new pediatric wing at the hospital? A presidential campaign? Name it. Anything.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You kicked us off your turf, Merk. Don't rain on our parade.

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Mr. Nelson, you disappoint me. First you break our school board rules. Then you break the law.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What law, Merk? Having fun? Letting down our hair on prom night?

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Our state has a zero tolerance policy for underage drinking.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You called the cops on us?

turns.speaker: PRINCIPAL MERKIN
turns.text: Alcohol does horrible things to a developing young mind.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Smashing!  Welcome to the family, Ted. You are going to breathe some new life into this place. You are going to set the world on fire! You are going to...call me Uncle Billy? Please?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, sure. Uncle Billy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I have only one concern...

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You do like girls, don't you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Of course I like girls.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: A lot? I mean, a whole lot?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: As much as possible.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You're sure?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: The parties are held in here when the weather dips below seventy. Which is seldom.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Seldom? No kidding?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Ah, in other words, this is the apres-orgy salon?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Indeed it is. During the day, visitors prefer to be outside, au naturel. As it were.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Maybe she needs help, Ted. You should be a gentleman.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I...uh...I think she's doing fine on her own.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: We don't allow TIPN, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Tipping?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: There you are, Ted-baby. Everything all right?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah.  Everything's cool.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You ready for your big coming out party? Everybody's dying to meet you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Just a couple of finishing touches. My parents always said you never get a second chance to make a good first impression.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: They said that? Really?  Oh, your parents. The Nelson's. Right, right. How midwest. I like that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Truth is, I'm a little nervous.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: YOU? Nervous? Why on earth should you be nervous?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All those people out there. It's a lot of pressure.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Huh! You laugh in the face of pressure!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I do?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You are a multi-media magnate. The Tycoon of Tits. The Baron of Bottoms.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You're the Sultan of Semen. The Monarch of Masturbation. The Merchant Prince of Lust. You. Ted. Are the King of Coitus.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Me? The King of Coitus?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: The Supreme Sovereign of Sexuality.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Whoa. But...that's the thing...  I've never even actually...

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Why, look who's here.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I told you you could do it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I was like a different person tonight.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You were the new and improved you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I would have been laughed right out of Xenia.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: No one will be laughing at you now, Ted. You can take that to the bank.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's really going to be strange going home in a couple of days.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You ARE home. But go ahead, finish school, do what you feel you need to do. In the meantime, I'll be your point person here on the magazine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really? You'd do that for me?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I've been very lazy for a long, long time.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You seem like you're anything but lazy, Uncle Billy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I never finished school myself. Never had to. My brother built this empire from nothing but his wife's perky tits and a whole lot of gumption. He gave me a cushy job on a silver platter. I never struggled for a second.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My parents always say hard work builds character.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: It's not like I didn't have ideas, I had plenty of ideas. But I never even shared them with your father. Never had the guts.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What kind of ideas?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Well...for one thing...I think it's despicable that we exclude so many women that only fit our western notion of "classic beauty."

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You think we should be more open minded?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: The world is a big, beautiful place.  We can open new markets in Africa and Asia.  Imagine the Dali Lhama reading our magazine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: In other words, our scope is too narrow.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: At our press conference tomorrow, I think we should announce our plans to explore the world. Not just a few leggy 36D's, with blond hair upstairs and down.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's perfect.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Don't forget to tell them all your qualifications.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm Ted Nelson. I guess you already know that part.  For two years I've been the editor of the high school paper in Xenia, Ohio. I've won some awards, made a difference. I've always had journalism in my soul. Now I know why.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: So far, so good. Some of them have real Angel potential.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really? So I'm doing OK?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My father must've been amazing.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: He was in a league of his own.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I never saw anybody turn so many shades of red.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I can't wait to see the pictures.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It was incredible. The light, the crowd, everything.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Such enthusiasm. Have I told you lately how proud I am of you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Seriously? I'm doing all right?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You're taking this bull of an empire by the horns, but you're still keeping your small town values. You're not letting all this "stuff" spoil you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I owe it all to you. Without your help I'd be lost.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I wish I knew you years ago, when my brother was alive. I wish he never gave you up.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, well, like my Grandpa used to say...you can't change your Christmas past, but you sure can exchange your Christmas presents.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'd love to, but I really need to crack the books.  Final exams are coming up and I've been slacking.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You're right. I should work, too. Our first issue together is almost ready to print.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thanks, Uncle Billy. Thanks for everything.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: You're a great kid. Don't you forget it.
